Quantum mechanics is a theory of continuous linear operators between Hilbert spaces. It is therefore natural to ask whether the category of continuous linear operators is equivalent to the category of sets and functions. We provide a purely categorical characterization of this equivalence, which is valid in any topos. This addresses a question about the foundations of quantum theory raised in reconstruction programs such as those of von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that cause diseases in a variety of hosts, including humans. Although the evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. Here, we report the results of a comparative analysis of the genomes of two distantly related species of myxozoans and a cnidarian parasite. Our results show that the myxozoan body plan is reduced to a minimum, and that the genome is one of the smallest reported in animals. This suggests that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. COVID-19 is a disease that has caused a global pandemic. The virus that causes COVID-19, SARS-CoV-2, is able to evade the host immune response by blocking the nuclear import of IFN-stimulated genes. In this study, we identified a viral protein, Orf6, that is able to block nuclear import of IFN-stimulated genes. We found that Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex and interacts with Nup98-Rae1, a protein complex that is involved in nuclear import. We show that Orf6 binding to Nup98-Rae1 disrupts the docking of the karyopherin/importin complex and prevents the import of IFN-stimulated genes. Our findings provide a mechanism of viral antagonism that could be used to design new antiviral strategies. (Less)

Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zinc is an important physiological inhibitor of these channels. Sperm cells are quiescent in the male reproductive system due to Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels, but become active once introduced into the low-Zn2+-concentration environment of the female reproductive tract. How Zn2+ inhibits proton channels is not completely understood. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the proton channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. Mutations of some proton channel residues affect only Zn2+ inhibition of the voltage sensor motion, whereas mutations of other residues also affect Zn2+ inhibition of gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric proton channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each proton channel subunit. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits proton channels will further our understanding of proton channel function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for proton channels. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by 2050, and the demand for food will increase by 50% to meet the needs of the growing urban population. This study shows that the variability of maize yields will increase substantially in the major maize-producing and -exporting countries as the Earth’s climate warms. This increase in variability will increase the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year in the top four maize-exporting countries, which account for 87% of global maize exports. The results also highlight the need for investments in breeding maize varieties that are more heat tolerant.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in African savannas. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level differences in diet. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant species of large herbivores in semiarid African savanna. We found that diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of species matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and that dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large herbivore assemblages, and that herbivore diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. This work provides a framework for understanding the role of niche partitioning in structuring large herbivore assemblages. It also provides a proof of concept for the application of DNA metabarcoding to the study of diet. This approach will be critical for understanding the role of niche partitioning in structuring large herbivore assemblages in other ecosystems.

We conducted a large survey of small businesses in the United States to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many small businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. However, the length of the crisis is a key determinant of business survival. Businesses with longer projections of the crisis are more likely to remain open. Moreover, many small businesses are financially fragile, with only a few weeks of cash on hand. Finally, many small businesses plan to apply for the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act, but anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris in the ocean is a major concern for the marine environment. However, the magnitude of the problem is still unknown. We show that the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This is due to size-selective sinks, such as nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The origin of the solar system is one of the most important questions in astronomy. The solar system is a unique laboratory for the study of the formation of the solar system and the early solar system. The solar system is also a unique laboratory for the study of the formation of the solar system and the early solar system.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the number of motorized vessels has increased exponentially. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to reproduce is the most important trait for the survival of a species. However, the mechanisms that limit reproductive output are poorly understood. Here, we show that the amount of energy available to the mother has a strong effect on reproductive output. We find that the amount of energy available to the mother is the greatest limiting factor on reproductive output in placental mammals. This result has implications for the evolution of the family, the domestication of animals, and the development of agriculture.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the presence of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. In this study, we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in a mouse model of MSA. This effect was associated with a reduction of the different forms of α-syn and with neuroprotection. Our results suggest that VX-765 is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This would be a major step forward in the treatment of MSA and other synucleinopathies. The results of this study also provide a rationale for the use of VX-765 in other neurodegenerative diseases. The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the interface between blood and tissue. It is the primary regulator of vascular function and the primary target of many drugs and diseases. The endothelium is a highly specialized cell type that is able to control vascular function in a highly specific and coordinated manner. This ability is achieved by the endothelium using a complex network of communication channels. The nature of this network has been poorly understood. Here, the nature of the endothelium communication network has been addressed using single-cell Ca2+ imaging across thousands of endothelial cells in intact blood vessels. The findings reveal that the endothelium is a highly connected, small-world network that is effective in both local and global communication. This finding has implications for the design of communication networks in general and may provide a framework for the design of new communication systems. It also provides a framework for understanding the endothelium’s role in vascular function and disease.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges, and the need for timely and accurate data has never been greater. We describe the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a wide range of data on the COVID-19 pandemic, including many auxiliary signals that are not typically available in public health surveillance. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This paper describes the data sources and signals, and provides examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making. We hope that the COVIDcast API will be useful to many stakeholders in the public health, epidemiological, and research communities. We also hope that the data and software will be useful to the many people who are working to contain the pandemic.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion channels in the human body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological processes, such as the control of heart rate and blood pressure, the transmission of nerve impulses, and the regulation of muscle contraction. The selectivity filter is the narrowest part of the channel and is responsible for the selective permeation of K+ ions. The activation gate is the part of the channel that opens and closes the channel. We have identified a key residue that is involved in the communication between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. We have also demonstrated that this residue is crucial for the structural changes that are required for the collapse of the selectivity filter during inactivation. This work provides a structural basis for the allosteric communication between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. It also provides a molecular understanding of the structural changes that are required for the collapse of the selectivity filter during inactivation. This knowledge will be useful for the development of new drugs that target potassium channels.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is influenced by the host and the host environment. The role of the gut microbiome in health and disease is just beginning to be understood, and the potential of the microbiome to be manipulated for therapeutic purposes is being explored. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the natural products of anaerobic fungi, which are a group of gut microbes that have not been previously studied for their potential to produce bioactive compounds. The results of this study provide a foundation for future research on the potential of anaerobic fungi to produce natural products that could be used for therapeutic purposes.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, yet the role of personality traits in the establishment of social hierarchy remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that predisposes individuals to become subordinate in a social encounter, directly influences social dominance and that this effect is mediated by mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. This work provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of personality traits in social behavior and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for anxiety disorders. The design of mechanical devices with complex and programmable behaviors is highly desired for various applications. However, the design space is restricted by the material properties and the structural patterns are often developed through trial and error. Here, we propose a synthesis strategy to design structures that can seamlessly collaborate through complex deformation mechanisms to achieve arbitrary and extreme responses under large deformations. The structures are digitally synthesized through a free-form inverse design approach, and the corresponding responses are physically realized in experiments. The proposed strategy can be extended to design structures with complex geometries and functionalities, and the resulting structures can be manufactured via multimaterial fabrication and heteroassembly. The proposed strategy can be utilized to design mechanical devices with complex and programmable behaviors for a wide range of applications.

Hemoglobin is the oxygen-binding protein of erythrocytes. The hemoglobin expression pattern in human erythrocytes is developmentally regulated, with fetal hemoglobin (HbF) being expressed in the fetus and newborn and adult hemoglobin (HbA) being expressed in adults. Here we show that the mRNA-binding protein IGF2BP1 is expressed in human erythroid tissues and is developmentally regulated, with a decrease in expression in the adult. We demonstrate that IGF2BP1 is a mediator of the developmental regulation of hemoglobin expression in humans.

Cancer is a leading cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we identified a mechanism of resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent peroxidation of phospholipids, in cancer cells. This resistance is mediated by mutation of phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) or loss of phosphatase and tensin homolog deleted on chromosome 10 (PTEN), two highly frequent events in cancer, and by activation of the mTOR signaling axis. This resistance is overcome by inhibition of the mTOR signaling axis, and the combination of mTOR inhibition with ferroptosis induction shows therapeutic promise in preclinical models. Our findings provide a molecular basis for the development of ferroptosis as a cancer therapy. (Read more)

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure, and the treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of cardiovascular disease prevention. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are calcium channel blockers, which are associated with a higher risk of heart failure than other antihypertensive drugs. Our study shows that the three major classes of calcium channel blockers activate store-operated Ca2+ entry in vascular smooth muscle cells, which is mediated by the N terminus of the STIM Ca2+ sensor protein. Our findings indicate that the activation of store-operated Ca2+ entry by calcium channel blockers promotes vascular remodeling and may be a target for the development of new drugs for the treatment of hypertension. This study also provides a rationale for the use of calcium channel blockers in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the management of 10 million hectares of federal forest in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP has not yet been successful in halting the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations. Our findings highlight the need to continue to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and to ensure that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. This problem can be addressed by the development of new antibacterial agents to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. In this study, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. This study provides a proof of concept for the use of computational predictions in the drug development process. Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often large, and the number of parameters required to achieve accurate results is often large. Here, we introduce a network architecture based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters, and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data.

The climate of the tropics is a key driver of the evolution of life on Earth. The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after the MPT. From 800 to 100 ka, a deep, often overfilled lake occupied the basin, indicating a wetter climate, but these highstands were interrupted by prolonged intervals

The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime has become increasingly common, but the effects of this exposure on sleep and health are unknown. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) for 1 h before bedtime suppresses melatonin secretion, phase-delays the circadian clock, and reduces the next-morning alertness and performance of healthy young adults. These results have important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas (YDB) cooling is one of the most enigmatic events in the Earth system. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the YDB cooling. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the Osmium isotope ratios of magnetic grains and bulk sediments from the YDB sites in Arizona, Michigan, New Mexico, New Jersey, and Ohio are similar to average upper continental crust, indicating a terrestrial origin of Os in these samples. In contrast, the Osmium isotope ratios of bulk sediments from YDB sites in Belgium and Pennsylvania suggest mixing with extraterrestrial Os, but the Os in these samples is likely terrestrially derived.

The role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity has been controversial. Here, we show that the role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity is complex and depends on the stage of the disease.

Beetles are the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We reconstructed the evolutionary history of beetles using a comprehensive dataset of genes from 521 species, including 146 species for which we reconstructed the entire genome. Our results show that the evolution of beetles was driven by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding enzymes that digest plant cell walls.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. View Full-Text

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to evolutionary psychologists. We report the results of a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results have implications for the evolution of technology and the development of human culture. They also highlight the importance of trial-and-error learning to the innovation and adaptation of technology. Finally, they suggest that the relationship between population size and CCE may be more complex than has been previously assumed. This work is a contribution to the debate on the role of culture in human evolution. It also has implications for the study of culture and evolution in general.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and the fifth leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing AD risk is the APOE genotype, which has three common isoforms, E2, E3, and E4. APOE4 is associated with a twofold increased risk for AD, whereas APOE2 is associated with a twofold decreased risk. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis of synapses, which is highly dependent on APOE isoform. We also found that APOE4 increases the rate of C1q accumulation in hippocampus, which may represent the accumulation of senescent synapses with enhanced vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that AD susceptibility of APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of C1q-coated senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is the densest part of the planet. It is a key to understanding the formation of the Earth and the dynamics of the core. However, the formation process of the inner core is still a mystery. In this study, we propose a two-step nucleation mechanism of the inner core. The first step is the nucleation of the bcc phase of iron, which is the stable phase at the inner core conditions. The second step is the transformation of the bcc phase to the hcp phase. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. (Abridged)

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are well established, the effects of acute marijuana use on the brain are less clear. Here, we show that the brain’s reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA), is reduced in marijuana abusers. This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, which are common symptoms of marijuana abuse. These findings have implications for the development of effective treatments for marijuana abuse.

Language is a uniquely human skill, and the brain’s mechanisms for comprehending it are the subject of intense study. Here, we use a large-scale, integrative modeling approach to reveal the brain’s predictive processing during language comprehension. We find that the most powerful deep learning models for natural language processing predict nearly 100% of the explainable variance in neural responses to sentences. Models’ fits to the data generalize across different datasets and even different modalities (functional MRI and electrocorticography). Model architecture appears to substantially contribute to neural fit. These results provide computational evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain. They also suggest that deep learning models may be a powerful tool for understanding the brain’s mechanisms for language processing.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major breakthrough in machine learning, but it has been plagued by instability. We show that this instability is due to the fact that many problems in machine learning are ill-conditioned, and thus, there are no algorithms that can compute stable neural networks. We introduce a new class of algorithms, called fast iterative restarted networks (FIRENETs), which we prove to be stable. Moreover, we prove that only O(|log (ϵ)|) layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem. Our results have implications for the theory of neural networks and for the design of algorithms for machine learning.

The COVID-19 pandemic has become a prime example of the failure of governments to contain the spread of a virus. In the midst of the crisis, scientists have repeatedly argued that the pandemic is caused by people’s inability to understand exponential growth. They point to a classic psychological experiment published 45 years prior to the first case of COVID-19, which they claim is a unique case study of the phenomenon. However, the experiment’s critical design flaws went completely unnoticed at the time and are discussed here as a cautionary tale against uncritically enshrining unsound research in the “lore” of a field of research. In hindsight, this is a unique case study of researchers falling prey to just the cognitive bias they set out to study.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years, and has been the subject of many studies. However, the cause of the disease has been unknown for a long time. In this study, we sequenced the genome of a bacterium that causes a reactional state known as Lucio's phenomenon, and found that it is very closely related to the cause of the other form of leprosy, known as lepromatous leprosy. This finding suggests that the two diseases are caused by the same organism, and that the two forms of leprosy are caused by the same organism that has undergone different evolutionary processes. This study also provides a framework for the study of the evolution of leprosy. (Less)

The study of the evolution of entanglement and entropy is a central topic in the physics of isolated quantum systems. It is also a fundamental problem in the foundations of quantum mechanics. In this work, we provide a complete solution to the problem of the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit. Our result is based on the integrability of the model and on the quasiparticle picture of the entanglement dynamics. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain and discuss its implications for the dynamics of entanglement in general.

COVID-19 is a pandemic that has caused more than 50 million cases and over 1.2 million deaths worldwide. The only vaccine currently in clinical development is based on a segment of the viral spike protein recoded with synonymous suboptimal codon pairs (codon-pair deoptimization), thereby introducing 283 silent (point) mutations. The furin cleavage site within the spike protein was deleted from the viral genome for added safety of the vaccine strain. The vaccine is temperature sensitive in vitro, yet grows robustly at the permissive temperature. In vivo studies in hamsters showed that the vaccine is protective at a single intranasal dose, reduces lung pathology, and reduces weight loss upon challenge with wild-type virus. This, coupled with its large-scale manufacturing potential, supports its potential use in mass vaccination programs. The vaccine is expected to be available in the second half of 2021. (Read more)

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of the disease is still debated, with the most common hypothesis being that rats were the main transmission pathway. However, this hypothesis is based on a few outbreaks and is not supported by quantitative data. Here, we propose a model for plague transmission by human ectoparasites, which is supported by quantitative data from nine outbreaks in Europe. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study also highlights the importance of quantitative data for the development of quantitative models.

The evolution of brain size is a key topic in the study of animal cognition. However, it is not the only factor that determines the cognitive capacity of an animal. In this study, we show that the evolution of brain size is not the only factor that determines the cognitive capacity of an animal. We also show that the evolution of the brain is not only about increasing the size of the brain but also about increasing the number of neurons. We show that the evolution of the brain is also about increasing the number of neurons in the brain.

TRAP1 is a mitochondrial molecular chaperone that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal and transformed cells is more complex than previously appreciated. We have shown that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings.

Actin filaments are the main cytoskeletal elements that are responsible for many cellular processes, including cell migration. However, they can also be harmful, as in the case of actin stress fibers, which are responsible for cell death. Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a protein that is involved in the regulation of actin filament dynamics. Here, we show that ADF can sever actin filaments, and we propose a mechanism that explains how this happens. Our results have implications for our understanding of the role of ADF in cells and for the design of new drugs.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in foods and beverages. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of sugar-sweetened beverages on appetite and weight gain.

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human history. It is the only island in the world where the Austronesian language family, which is the language family of the majority of the world’s population, is spoken. This paper provides a detailed picture of the human history of Madagascar, which is a key step in understanding the origin and the spread of the Austronesian language family.

The ribosome is the enzyme that translates mRNA into protein. It is a large, complex machine that is able to read mRNA sequences and translate the information into a polypeptide chain. The ribosome is also able to make decisions about which amino acid to add to the growing polypeptide chain based on the sequence of the mRNA. In this study, we show that the presence of a modification in the mRNA sequence can alter the decision-making process of the ribosome. This study has implications for our understanding of the role of mRNA modifications in the translation process.

This study shows that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, social relationships, and use of time. This finding has implications for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging.

The evolution of larger body size is a defining feature of the evolution of mammals. This study shows that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. The existence of this body size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. These three independent body size increases and a shared aquatic optimum size are consistent with control by differences in the scaling of energetic intake and cost functions with body size between the terrestrial and aquatic realms. Under this energetic model, thermoregulatory costs constrain minimum size, whereas limitations on feeding efficiency constrain maximum size. The optimum size occurs at an intermediate value where thermoregulatory costs are low but feeding efficiency remains high. Rather than being released from size pressures, water-dwelling mammals are driven and confined to larger body sizes by the strict energetic demands of the aquatic medium. (Abridged)

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. Although rhinovirus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at the core body temperature, the mechanism of temperature-dependent growth is not known. Here, we show that mouse airway cells infected with mouse-adapted rhinovirus exhibit a striking enrichment in expression of antiviral defense response genes at 37 °C relative to 33 °C. This correlates with higher expression levels of type I and type III IFN genes and IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs) at 37 °C. These findings demonstrate that in mouse airway cells, rhinovirus replicates preferentially at nasal cavity temperature due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. These results have implications for the development of antiviral strategies for the common cold. (PsycINFO Database Record

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a major cause of infections in humans and animals. It is an opportunistic pathogen that infects patients with compromised immune systems, and it is responsible for a wide range of infections, including pneumonia, sepsis, and urinary tract infections. The bacterium is also a major threat to the food industry, as it causes infections in both animals and humans that are associated with the consumption of contaminated meat and seafood. In this study, we show that P. aeruginosa uses its type IV pili to sense the mechanical activity of the pili, and that this sensing mechanism is required for the regulation of virulence. Our findings have implications for our understanding of the role of pili in bacterial motility and virulence, and they also have implications for the development of new strategies for the control of infections caused by this pathogen.

The importance of agricultural pesticides in surface water has been underestimated due to a lack of comprehensive quantitative analysis. This study provides a global metaanalysis of peer-reviewed studies that evaluates, for the first time to our knowledge on a global scale, the exposure of surface waters to particularly toxic agricultural insecticides. Our results show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human health and the global economy. However, the role of animals in the transmission of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, has not been well studied. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, a species that is susceptible to severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 infection. Our findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and highlight the need for a proactive “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. Our study also provides a model for the surveillance of zoonotic diseases in wildlife. (Less)

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, the economy, and the social well-being of the people living in the areas where they are built. This paper examines the reasons for the proliferation of large dams in the developing world and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) protein is the primary component of Aβ plaques and neurofibrillary tangles. However, the immune response in AD is often attributed to microglial activation in response to Aβ. Here, we show that neurons are also capable of producing a variety of potent immune factors, and that these are present in the brain before the formation of Aβ plaques. We propose that the Aβ-burdened neuron is a primary proinflammatory agent, implicating the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ as a significant immunological component in the AD pathogenesis. Our findings have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for AD.

The domestic chicken is one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, the earliest evidence for its economic exploitation is still unknown. We present a detailed analysis of the faunal assemblage from the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, and show that the exploitation of chickens for economic purposes was widespread in the Southern Levant during the fourth–second centuries B.C.E. This result is supported by a survey of the Southern Levant, which shows a sharp increase in the frequency of chicken during the Hellenistic period. We suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later.

The folding of a protein is a complex process, and it is not yet clear how many distinct steps are involved. This work shows that the maltose binding protein, a large protein, folds through distinct steps, and that the steps are not all on the same pathway. The results are important for understanding the folding of other proteins.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been linked to the formation of caps on RNA molecules. However, the cellular concentration of Np4 increases in response to conditions of disulfide stress, and the predominant decapping enzyme in proteobacteria, ApaH, is inactivated by those conditions. Here, we show that, in cells experiencing disulfide stress, the pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is known to decapturate Np4-capped RNAs, is also capable of decapping those transcripts. Unexpectedly, RppH prefers to decapturate capped RNAs over their capped counterparts, and the unique manner in which capped substrates bind to the active site of RppH positions the δ-phosphate, rather than the β-phosphate, for hydrolytic attack, generating triphosphorylated RNA as the primary product of decapping. This work provides a mechanistic explanation for the differential impact of Np4 on the rates at which capped and uncapped 5′ ends are deprotected as a prelude to RNA degradation. The implications of this work for the regulation of gene expression during disulfide stress are discussed. (Read more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcomes. Although the immune system is the main target of sepsis, it is also responsible for the development of the disease. In this study, we demonstrate that arginine, a key amino acid in the urea cycle, is essential for the maintenance of T cell function during sepsis. Our results suggest that arginine supplementation could be a promising strategy to improve the outcome of sepsis patients.

The biomass of the biosphere is the total amount of carbon stored in all of the living organisms on Earth. It is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined and highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a quantitative view of the biomass composition of the biosphere and can be used to understand the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. They also provide a baseline for future studies on the impact of human activities on the global biomass of different taxa.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in which a dynamical system evolves in a critical state, in which small perturbations can lead to large changes. SOC is observed in a variety of natural and man-made systems, including earthquakes, sandpiles, fire spreading, neural networks, and financial markets. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a continuous model of SOC. Our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and chemical inertness. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum devices, and sensors. However, its electronic properties are difficult to control due to its small bandgap. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its bandgap can be fully closed, by applying strain. We also show that diamond can be demetallized, and its bandgap can be opened, by applying pressure. Our findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. This work also provides a general framework for exploring the relationship between strain and electronic properties of solids. This work is expected to be a milestone in the field of strain engineering of solids.

The study of the structure and function of peptides is a major area of research in the field of protein chemistry. The discovery of the structure of the first protein, myoglobin, in 1958 by the Nobel laureate, John Kendrew, and the subsequent discovery of the structure of DNA in 1953 by Watson and Crick, led to the development of the field of protein chemistry. The discovery of the structure of the first peptide, insulin, in 1921 by Frederick Banting and Charles Best, led to the development of the field of peptide chemistry. The discovery of the structure of the first cysteine-rich peptide, Nodule-specific cysteine-rich peptide, in 1999 by the Nobel laureate, Rogerio de Azevedo, led to the development of the field of cysteine-rich peptide chemistry.

The male–female reproductive interface is the site of the most intimate interactions between the sexes. In this study, we provide a comprehensive characterization of the proteome dynamics of the Drosophila sperm during the posttesticular period. We show that the proteome of the sperm is dramatically altered after mating, and we demonstrate that female contributions to the sperm proteome are critical for sperm viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the proteome dynamics of the sperm during the posttesticular period and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. This work will be of interest to the broader scientific community and to the public interested in the reproductive biology of animals.

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that is essential for the adhesion of platelets to damaged blood vessels. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that force can be used to switch the conformation of VWF, providing a mechanism for the regulation of VWF function. This mechanism is important for understanding the effects of VWD mutations and may be relevant to other diseases in which force is applied to proteins.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been the focus of intense study for the past decade. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been more difficult to study, and the lack of a comprehensive database has hindered the ability to understand the role of viruses in human health. This study addresses this gap, and provides a resource for the study of viruses in the human microbiome. The database is freely available, and can be used to study the impact of viruses on human health.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, the ACI is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of the ACI process and the lack of observational capability. To overcome this conundrum, we introduce the dual-field-of-view (FOV) high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL) for simultaneously profiling aerosol and water cloud properties, especially water cloud microphysical properties. This instrument, verified by the Monte Carlo simulation and coincident observations of other techniques, was used to conduct continuous observations of aerosols and clouds over Beijing. The observations show that the ACI process is complex and difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. It is expected to provide a significant contribution to the ACI investigations. This technique is expected to become a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. Thus, it is expected to have a significant impact on the climate science. The temperature of Earth’s surface has a profound influence on the evolution of life. However, the temperature of the surface of the early Earth is unknown. Here, we report the thermostability of ancestral enzymes, which are the precursors of the enzymes found in the present-day world. Our results suggest that the temperature of the surface of the early Earth was higher than previously thought.

Ion channels are the main ion-conducting proteins in the cell membrane. They are also the main targets of drugs. Ion channels are open or closed, and the open probability is determined by the channel conformation. Ion channels have two types of gates, one for fast activation/deactivation and the other for slow inactivation. We found that the BK channel, which is a large-conductance calcium-activated potassium channel, has no classic activation gate and shows no C-type inactivation. We also found that the BK channel’s C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of ion channels. (Less)

Malaria is a disease that affects millions of people worldwide, and the development of new treatments is urgently needed. One of the most important steps in the parasite’s life cycle is the invasion of the red blood cell, which is the target of the parasite’s infection. Here, we show that the parasite’s erythrocyte-binding antigen, EBA175, alters the biophysical properties of the red blood cell membrane, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This finding suggests that the parasite primes the erythrocyte surface through its binding antigens, altering the biophysical nature of the target cell and thus reducing a critical energy barrier to invasion. This would constitute a major change in our concept of malaria parasite invasion, suggesting it is, in fact, a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. This work provides a new perspective on the invasion process and could lead to the development of new strategies for malaria control. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and chemical inertness. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum devices, and sensors. However, its electronic properties are not fully understood, and its bandgap is not tunable. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its bandgap can be tuned reversibly by strain engineering. We also show that diamond can be used as a strain sensor, and that it can be used as a phase-transition thermometer. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. This work also provides a general framework for exploring the relationship between electronic and phonon structures in solids. This framework can be applied to other materials for further understanding of their properties. It can also be applied to other fields, such as biology and medicine, for understanding the relationship between electronic and mechanical structures in biological and medical materials. Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In the temperate regions, seasonal influenza virus outbreaks correlate closely with decreases in humidity. While low ambient humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that inhalation of dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings have implications for the development of strategies to mitigate the impact of influenza virus infection in low humidity environments. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The brain is thought to build syntactic structures by merging words into phrases. Whether and how the brain does this remains unknown. Here, we show that high-gamma power in multiple regions of the brain increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases suddenly whenever words can be merged into a phrase. This provides evidence for a merge operation that applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. More superficial models of language, based on sequential transition probabilities, only captured activity in the posterior middle temporal gyrus. Our results suggest that the brain implements a bottom-up or left-corner parser of the incoming language stream. They also provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists. Our findings have implications for theories of language processing and for the design of artificial intelligence.

Axin is a key component of the Wnt pathway, which is involved in the development of many tissues. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin in vertebrates are not only similar at the protein level but also in their regulation. We show that the two forms of Axin are regulated in a similar manner in different tissues, and that this regulation is important for the tissue-specific function of the pathway.

Obesity is a major health problem in the United States and worldwide. It is associated with a number of chronic diseases, including type 2 diabetes, cardiovascular disease, and certain types of cancer. The causes of obesity are complex and include genetic and environmental factors. However, the brain is a major contributor to the development of obesity. Here we describe a circuit in the brain that may contribute to overeating and contribute to the development of obesity.

Nitrogen is the most important nutrient for plant growth, and the ability to fix nitrogen in the soil would be a major advance in agriculture. However, the symbiosis between plants and nitrogen-fixing bacteria is complex and difficult to control, and the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the plant. Here, we have developed a system that allows us to control the nitrogen-fixing activity of bacteria in the soil, and we have demonstrated that this system can be used to control the nitrogen-fixing activity of bacteria in the plant. This work represents a major step toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work also provides a proof of concept for the use of rhizopine as a synthetic signal for the control of nitrogen-fixing bacteria.

We study the effects of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that was designed to reduce deforestation by facilitating transfer of early deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities and incentivizing community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss in the communities that participated in the program, but the estimated effects are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals are surrounded by sound, and hearing is a fundamental sense of many animals. The auditory organs of these animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet they are all made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the body of the animal. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is outsourced to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. We find that the orb web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to sense the motion of web threads that approaches the maximum physical efficiency better than the acoustic responsivity of all previously known eardrums. By outsourcing its acoustic sensors to its web, the spider is released from body size constraints and permits the araneid spider to increase its sound-sensitive surface area enormously, up to 10,000 times greater than the spider itself. The outsourcing and supersizing of auditory function in spiders provides unique features for studying extended and regenerative sensing and designing novel acoustic flow detectors for precise fluid dynamic measurement and manipulation. We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic has resulted in over 5 million deaths worldwide. The need for a global vaccine supply is urgent, and the development of a vaccine based on the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of SARS-CoV-2 spike protein has the potential to provide a cost-effective and scalable solution. Here, we report the design and characterization of an engineered RBD that is suitable for large-scale production and has the potential to be used in a vaccine.

Neuroblastoma is the most common tumor of neural crest-derived tissues in children. The molecular mechanisms of neuroblastoma development and progression are not fully understood. Here, we show that zebrafish ALK-like receptors (alkals) are involved in the development of neural crest-derived tissues. We also provide evidence that the three zebrafish ALKALs are able to activate the ALK/LTK family of receptors in vivo. Our results provide a molecular basis for the involvement of ALK/LTK receptors in neural crest development and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for neuroblastoma.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and its origins are shrouded in mystery. Here, we present the genomes of 17 Yersinia pestis strains from the Late Neolithic to the Bronze Age, providing a unique opportunity to explore the evolution of this pathogen over millennia. Our results reveal a single lineage of Y. pestis that persisted over time without significant diversification, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents. We also discover the presence of the flea-adapted form of Y. pestis in Bronze Age Iberia, previously only identified in the Caucasus and the Volga regions, suggesting a much wider geographic spread of this form of Y. pestis. Together, these data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years in terms of its early evolution and ecology. This work provides a unique perspective on the origins of one of the most devastating diseases in human history. View Full-Text

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity (hegemonic masculinity) and their support for Donald Trump. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 American presidential election, women’s and men’s endorsement of hegemonic masculinity predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of hegemonic masculinity legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. Future research should examine the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of hegemonic masculinity and support for other political candidates and leaders. This work has implications for understanding the political climate in the United States and around the world.

The agricultural use of grasslands has been shown to be a major driver of soil organic carbon (SOC) loss to the atmosphere. However, the extent to which this trend can be reversed by adopting soil health management practices remains highly uncertain. We show that soil health management practices can increase SOC storage and mineral-associated organic carbon, but the extent to which these practices can offset the SOC loss from grassland-derived Mollisols remains unclear. We also show that the effects of soil health management practices on soil microbial traits are highly dependent on the crop rotation and the addition of manure. Our results highlight the importance of well-managed grasslands in climate-smart agriculture.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of zoonotic viruses to humans and for the development of strategies to mitigate that risk. We have developed a framework and interactive web tool, SpillOver, that can be used to identify and prioritize viruses with the greatest potential to cause future outbreaks of pandemic severity. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to animals for pollination. The color of nectar is an important trait that attracts animals, but the mechanisms underlying the production of the color are not well understood. We show that the color of the red nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify a mechanism for the production of this color in other plants, and provide evidence that this trait is convergent in two species visited by hummingbirds. This work provides insight into the evolution of a key trait in the plant–animal interaction. It also suggests that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work may have implications for the study of the evolution of color in animals and the origin of vertebrate-pollination. (Less)

The history of Europe is marked by waves of migration, which have shaped the genetic structure of the continent. However, the genetic history of the population during the period of cultural change is largely unknown. Here, we present a study of a large sample of genomes from Bavaria, Germany, dating to the late 5th/early 6th century AD. Our results indicate that the genetic ancestry of men is mostly modern, while women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity. This heterogeneity includes signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we found that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These findings provide insights into the demographic processes that shaped the genetic structure of Europe during the period of cultural change. (Less)

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. We describe the use of a global cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform to investigate the pathogen landscape of undifferentiated febrile illness in a resource-scarce setting. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens, including chikungunya virus, which presaged a national outbreak. Our results highlight the need for ongoing pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings to better understand the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and to deploy rapid public health response. This work is a proof of concept for the use of mNGS in resource-scarce settings and can be used to guide the development of similar surveillance programs in other low- and middle-income countries.

The human genome is replicated in a complex process that involves the assembly of a complex sliding clamp, proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA), onto the DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) complex. This process is essential for the faithful replication of the lagging strand template and is integral to the maintenance of genome stability. However, the stability of the human pol δ holoenzyme has not been determined. Here, we report a unique kinetic assay that allows us to measure the processivity and stability of the human pol δ holoenzyme. Our results indicate that the human pol δ holoenzyme is not as stable as the S. cerevisiae pol δ holoenzyme and that the human pol δ holoenzyme is not as processive as the S. cerevisiae pol δ holoenzyme. These results have implications for the replication of the human genome.

The origin of life is one of the most important problems in biology. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by ribozymes. In the laboratory, RNA molecules can be replicated by ribozymes, but the process is inefficient. Here, we describe a method for improving the activity of ribozymes that can be used to increase the efficiency of RNA replication in the laboratory. The improved ribozyme can replicate RNA molecules, amplify RNA templates, and synthesize a variety of functional RNA molecules, including aptamers, ribozymes, and tRNA. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearance of five US cities with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our work also provides a proof of concept for a new type of urban monitoring system that can be used to study the physical dynamics of cities.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is still unclear. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets interleukin 6 pathways, is effective in the treatment of severe and critical COVID-19 patients. The results of this study provide a reference for the clinical treatment of COVID-19.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but also a toxic metal that can cause oxidative damage. The ability of fungi to regulate copper homeostasis is well established, but the existence of copper-binding fungal natural products has not been demonstrated. Here we show that the xan biosynthetic gene cluster in Aspergillus fumigatus encodes a family of isocyanide metabolites that bind copper and have antimicrobial properties. The existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This work provides insight into the evolution of copper homeostasis in fungi and the potential for the discovery of novel antifungal compounds. This article is protected by copyright. The formation of silica minerals in the martian environment is a key to understanding the origin and evolution of the planet. The detection of tridymite in a sedimentary mudstone at the base of a crater wall/rim/central peak suggests that the martian surface was once covered by a large body of water.

Frost events are a major source of crop and animal losses, and their impact on forests is often underestimated. We show that the geographic distribution of frost events is changing, and that this change is likely to increase the risk of frost damage in some regions. Our findings can inform decision-making in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory response in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the functional significance of this response is not clear. We show that the development of Th17 cells is contingent on the expression of both Stat4 and T-bet, but not the IL-12 or IFN-γ receptors. Moreover, Th17 cells can provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. This dual role for Th17 cells may be important for the development of disease in inflammatory bowel disease.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, which are the cells responsible for generating muscle movement. We have previously shown that motor neuron toxicity in ALS can be caused by human astrocytes, which are the cells that surround and protect motor neurons. Here, we report a method to convert human fibroblasts from living ALS patients into induced neuronal progenitor cells and subsequent differentiation into astrocytes. This method now enables rapid disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening to alleviate astrocyte-derived toxicity. This will greatly facilitate ALS research and development of therapeutics.

The ability of pathogens to influence the composition of the host microbiota is a key factor in the transmission of infectious diseases. Here, we show that the tick-borne pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum alters the gut microbiota of its vector, the blacklegged tick, Ixodes scapularis, to enhance its colonization. We demonstrate that the pathogen induces the tick to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the integrity of the gut barrier and the ability of bacteria to form biofilms. These findings provide insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the microbiota of their vectors and may have implications for the control of vector-borne diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Birds are a highly diverse group of animals, and the study of their evolution has been a central topic in avian systematics for over a century. However, the study of the early evolution of birds has been hindered by a lack of fossils, and the study of the earliest members of the group has been further complicated by the presence of a group of birds with a short tail, called “pygostylians,” that is thought to have evolved from long-tailed basal birds. Here, we describe a new basal member of the group, and show that it represents an important step in the evolution of the avian bauplan.

We show that the tropical tropopause layer plays an important role in the climate system. This comes from analysis of observations showing that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue, and many of them are able to change their color. This phenomenon is called color polymorphism. In this study, we show that the occurrence of blue-green colors in vertebrates has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history, and that the color is controlled by a mechanism that is similar to the one that controls the color of plants. Our results provide a molecular and functional explanation for the evolution of color polymorphism in vertebrates.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer among women worldwide, and the leading cause of cancer death among women. Breast cancer cells are characterized by the ability to form cancer stem cells (CSCs), which are responsible for the initiation and recurrence of the disease. In this study, we show that hypoxia induces expression of AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which in turn regulates the expression of NANOG, a gene that encodes a pluripotency factor. NANOG expression is enriched in CSCs, and ALKBH5 overexpression increases the percentage of CSCs in breast cancer cells. Thus, ALKBH5 is a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer.

The Bible was the first book to be printed, and the first printed books were pocket Bibles. The parchment used to make these books was a key innovation in the history of printing. The source of this parchment has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. The method is based on the use of a PVC eraser to extract protein from the parchment surface, followed by analysis of the extracted proteins by mass spectrometry. The method is noninvasive and can be used to identify the animal origin of parchment from the past.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction event in the last 542 My. The cause of the extinction is still debated, but the timing of the event is well established. Here we provide a precise age model for the extinction and its aftermath, which will allow a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction. This will allow insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion and will establish an accurate time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms.

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that is involved in various biological processes, including circadian rhythm, cancer, and metabolism. However, the function of RORα in the intestine is still unclear. Here, we generated intestinal epithelial cell (IEC)-specific RORα-deficient (RORαΔIEC) mice and found that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORαΔIEC mice exhibit excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Transcriptome analysis reveals that deletion of RORα leads to up-regulation of NF-κB target genes in IECs. Chromatin immunoprecipitation analysis reveals corecruitment of RORα and histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3) on NF-κB target promoters and subsequent dismissal of CREB binding protein (CBP) and bromodomain-containing protein 4 (BRD4) for transcriptional repression.
