The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. We have determined the structure of the spike glycoprotein in complex with the receptor ACE2 at 3.0 Å resolution. The structure of the spike glycoprotein in complex with ACE2 provides a basis for understanding the mechanism of viral entry and for the design of vaccines and therapeutics.

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. Black and Latino Americans have experienced a disproportionate burden of COVID-19 morbidity and mortality, reflecting persistent structural inequalities that increase risk of exposure to COVID-19 and mortality risk for those infected. We estimate life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for 2020, for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. Our medium estimate indicates a reduction in US life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y to 77.48 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. The chemical behavior of atoms and molecules is the basis of chemistry. It is therefore of great interest to understand the behavior of atoms under pressure, which is a key parameter in many experiments and applications. Here, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, such as electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and we show that this is consistent with pressure-induced metallization. Furthermore, we show that the pseudo–noble-gas elements Ni, Pd, and Pt become electron acceptors, while the pseudo–metal elements Fe, Co, Rh, and Ir become electron donors. We show the explicative and predictive power of our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales. This work is a step toward a better understanding of the chemical behavior of atoms under pressure.

Fire is a key climate-driven disturbance in terrestrial ecosystems, but the effects of climate change on fire activity are poorly understood. We show that changes in human demography, as caused by socioeconomic development, can have a large influence on fire activity, with implications for the global carbon cycle. We find that changes in human demography tend to suppress global fire activity, keeping more carbon within terrestrial ecosystems and attenuating warming. However, the risk of more extreme fires regionally and with implications for other ecosystem functions in fire-dependent ecosystems means that climate–carbon cycle feedbacks are most effective at slowing global warming under lower emission scenarios. Our study highlights the importance of fire in the global carbon cycle and the need to understand the effects of climate and human demography on fire regimes.

The mutualism between symbiotic bacteria and their animal hosts is one of the most ancient and widespread forms of symbiosis. The bacteria provide essential nutrients, and the hosts provide a suitable environment and a source of behavioral cues. However, the mechanisms by which the hosts regulate the activities of their symbionts are not well understood. Here, we show that the delivery of a single glycan, chitin, is sufficient to regulate the activities of the symbionts and the health of the mutualism. This glycan is provided by the host only at night, when the animal is active and the symbionts are metabolically active. This study provides a mechanism for the regulation of the activities of symbionts in animal microbiomes. It also suggests that the delivery of specific nutrients may be a general mechanism for the regulation of the activities of symbionts in animal microbiomes. (Less)

Text data are ubiquitous, and the need for methods to identify latent patterns in them is growing. We introduce a method to identify topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. We use a sparse representation of an embedding space to identify a set of latent topics that can be interpreted as latent topics. We can also infer the topic that generated a sequence of words. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System (NVDRS). The NVDRS summarizes violent death incidents with structured variables and unstructured narratives. We identify 225 latent topics in the narratives (e.g., preparation for death and physical aggression); many of these topics are not captured by existing structured variables. Motivated by known patterns in suicide and homicide by gender and recent research on gender biases in semantic space, we identify the gender bias of our topics (e.g., a topic about pain medication is feminine). We then compare the gender bias of topics to their prevalence in narratives of female versus male victims. Results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE, via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. This pandemic is generally understood as the consequence of a singular introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. To locate these putative plague reservoirs, we studied the climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague epidemics, based on a dataset of 7,711 georeferenced historical plague outbreaks and 15 annually resolved tree-ring records from Europe and Asia. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. This study provides a new perspective on the history of the plague pandemic and its impact on human societies. View Full-Text

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and are important ecosystem engineers. They are also a valuable resource for the fishing industry and for the aquarium trade. In the past few years, a disease has been observed that has caused the mass mortality of large numbers of asteroids. We show that the disease is caused by a virus and that it is highly contagious. The virus is likely to be a major threat to the sustainability of the asteroid fishery and to the survival of the asteroid population.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a disease with a poor prognosis, and there is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies. We show that monoclonal antibodies targeting interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. View Full-Text

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human history. It is the only island in the world where the Austronesian language family, which is the language family of the majority of the world’s population, is spoken. This paper provides a detailed picture of the human history of Madagascar, which is a key step in understanding the origin of the Austronesian language family.

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA. Consistent with this observation, we found that cadA and galE are repressed by base pairing with the RNA. Interestingly, AzuC translation interferes with the observed repression of cadA and galE by the RNA and base pairing interferes with AzuC translation, demonstrating that the translation and base-pairing functions compete. The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. View Full-Text

Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop status in many countries. However, their assessments are subjective and qualitative, and are not easily amenable to quantitative analysis. We propose a method to convert the original crop expert data into a continuous probabilistic variable that can be used for quantitative analysis. We show that the resulting probabilistic variable is robust across different crops, and has nation-wide validity. We also demonstrate how the probabilistic variable can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our results show that the crop expert data can be used to provide a more complete picture of crop conditions, and can be used to improve the accuracy of agricultural forecasts. This will help farmers and policy makers to make better decisions and mitigate risks.

Language is a complex system that involves the ability to integrate information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the brain that is based on changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is based on the idea that information is stored in the adaptive changes in the conductances of neurons, and that this information can be read back into the membrane potential for processing. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and can be used to integrate information over time.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to the scientific community and the public. However, despite considerable scientific attention in recent decades, the overall response of soil respiration to anticipated climatic warming remains unclear. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. The 2015–2017 drought in southwestern South Africa was the worst in the region in the last century. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of this drought by a factor of five to six. This result is robust to the choice of model and emission scenario. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5 [SSP2-4.5]) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). This result highlights the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions.

The discovery of quasicrystals in the aftermath of the first nuclear test, the “Trinity test,” in 1945, was a major event in the history of science. It was the first time that a new class of materials had been discovered, and it was the first time that a new class of materials had been used in a weapon. Here, we report the discovery of a hitherto unknown composition of icosahedral quasicrystal in red trinitite, the first sample of sand to be exposed to the radiation of a nuclear explosion.

Photosynthesis is the basis of life on Earth. The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophylls is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. This work reveals the evolution of the enzymes that catalyze the formation of the isocyclic fifth ring in these pigments.

Neuroinflammation is a major contributor to the pathogenesis of multiple sclerosis (MS), and neuroinflammation is known to be regulated by mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase, neuroinflammation-associated kinase 1 (ASK1). However, the precise cellular and molecular mechanisms of ASK1 in neuroinflammation remain unknown. In this study, we found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in neuroinflammation, and ASK1 in astrocytes plays a major role in the later stage of neuroinflammation. Our findings suggest that ASK1 is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study also provides a better understanding of the role of ASK1 in neuroinflammation and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for neuroinflammatory diseases. The 2012–2014 drought in California was the driest and warmest in the state’s instrumental history. We show that the probability of drought years in California has increased in recent decades because of human activities. Our results are based on a statistical analysis of historical climate observations and climate model simulations.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk gene homologs with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a framework for understanding the etiology of autism and for developing a strategy to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms. It also provides a model system to study the function of the autism-risk genes and the mechanisms of behavioral flexibility. (PsycINFO Database Record

This work is the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date. It also highlights individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. Insofar as our results make clear the pervasiveness of negativity biases on average, they help account for the tendency for audience-seeking news around the world to be predominantly negative. Insofar as our results highlight individual-level variation, however, they highlight the potential for more positive content, and suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The store-operated Ca2+ (Ca2+) (SO(2)) channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ signaling, and mutations in the proteins that form the channel pore or the Ca2+ sensor result in severe immune dysfunction and muscle disease. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of the Ca2+ sensor, STIM1, and in the pore-forming protein of the SO(2) channel, ORAI1, that result in a spectrum of clinical features, including bleeding diathesis, thrombocytopenia, and tubular myopathy. These data expand our understanding of the molecular basis of SO(2) channel function and suggest new therapeutic strategies for patients with Stormorken syndrome and related conditions. (Stormorken syndrome is a term used to describe a group of conditions that share a common clinical phenotype.) (Read more)

Neurodegenerative diseases are characterized by the accumulation of misfolded proteins in the brain. These proteins aggregate and spread throughout the brain, causing damage to neurons. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are not well understood. Here we show that the spread of polyglutamine-expanded huntingtin in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease is non–cell-autonomous, and that the spreading of aggregates causes damage to neurons. We also show that the spread of aggregates is dependent on active release and uptake of aggregates, and that this spreading can be prevented by inhibiting endocytosis in vulnerable neurons. These results provide a framework for understanding the mechanisms of spreading and the propagation of neurodegenerative disease. They also provide a platform for the development of new therapeutic strategies.

Bats are increasingly accepted as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks through spillover to other animals and humans. However, our understanding of the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats is very limited. Here, we identified and characterized an immunosuppressant protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the role of MTX in the immune system and its potential as a therapeutic target for the prevention of viral infection. This study may also provide a deeper understanding of the role of MTX in the immune system and its potential as a therapeutic target for the prevention of viral infection. (PsycINFO Database Record

Cancer is a disease of rapid cell growth, and the one-carbon unit is essential for this process. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of both human serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) 1 and 2, and have shown that this inhibitor blocks colon cancer tumor growth. We have also shown that the one-carbon donor, formate, is a potent rescue of SHMT inhibition in cancer cells, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in a subset of cancer cell lines. This effect is rooted in defective glycine import, and thus defective glycine metabolism, in these cancer cells. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of cancer cells.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no known cause or cure. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord of ALS patients are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. To explain the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in ALS, we observe that they have an average supersaturation even greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners in motor neurons, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. Our findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for ALS. (PsycINFO Database Record

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. An optical conveyor technique is presented for continuously loading atoms into the desired trapping positions with optimal coupling to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter.

The Cretaceous period is often considered the age of dinosaurs, but it was also the age of the origin of many flowering plants. The study of the early evolution of the angiosperms, the group that includes all modern flowering plants, is poorly understood. Here we present a detailed study of Montsechia vidalii, a Cretaceous aquatic angiosperm that opens the possibility that aquatic plants were locally common at a very early stage of angiosperm evolution and that aquatic habitats may have played a major role in the diversification of some early angiosperm lineages.

The study of ancient viruses is important for understanding the evolution of viruses and the origin of new viral lineages. Here we present the genomes of five ancient parvoviruses from human remains that date back to ∼0.5 kya. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is placed ∼12.6 kya, and we are able to date the recombination event between genotypes 1 and 3 that formed genotype 2 to ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Less)

Sea level is a key indicator of global climate change. In this study, we show that the rate of sea level rise is accelerating, and that this acceleration is consistent with the rate of acceleration of the climate system. This result is important because it shows that the rate of sea level rise is not a fixed quantity, but is instead a function of the rate of climate change.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain has increased with age in the United States for all adults, but that the increase has been more rapid for those born after 1950. This pattern is not explained by changes in occupation or levels of obesity, but fits a more general pattern seen in the ongoing erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950. If this trend continues, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults; importantly, tomorrow’s elderly will be sicker than today’s elderly, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of enzymology. In this work, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed, chemically characterized picture of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate, a defining species for pyridoxal-5′-phosphate–dependent enzymes that catalyze β-elimination and replacement reactions. This integrated approach provides insight into both structure and chemical dynamics, and it offers a detailed picture of the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state. The results highlight the importance of the crystallographic waters in the active site and the role of the α-aminoacrylate hydroxyl leaving group in the reaction mechanism. The results also provide a chemically detailed picture of the reaction of the α-aminoacrylate intermediate with benzimidazole, an isostere of the natural substrate indole.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus. There is no licensed antiviral treatment for MERS, and the available options are limited. In this study, we show that remdesivir, an investigational broad-spectrum antiviral, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in a nonhuman primate model. This study supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial of MERS-CoV infection, and may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This study also highlights the importance of continued research on the development of antiviral treatments for emerging and reemerging coronaviruses. This article is protected by copyright. The mutualism between symbiotic bacteria and their animal hosts is one of the most ancient and widespread forms of symbiosis. The bacteria, in exchange for a safe habitat, provide the animal with a variety of nutrients that are essential for the host’s health. However, the mechanisms that regulate the provision of these nutrients are still poorly understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is critical for the maintenance of a symbiotic relationship between a squid and its luminescent bacteria. This glycan is provided by the squid’s immune cells, which are released into the symbiotic crypts at dusk, and its catabolism is required for the acidification of the habitat of the bacteria. This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of symbiosis, and it may have implications for the study of other types of mutualism. View Full-Text

This paper describes a series of experiments that tested whether teachers could be encouraged to adopt an empathic rather than punitive mindset about discipline. We found that teachers’ mindsets about discipline directly affect the quality of teacher–student relationships and student suspensions, and that these mindsets can be changed through scalable intervention. This work has implications for the future of school discipline and the future of the American education system.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can lead to mutagenesis and cancer. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated the impact of alkylation on transcription. We found that the transcription process is sensitive to the regioisomeric DNA alkylation. The results from the present in vitro transcriptional studies are well correlated with in vivo transcriptional mutagenesis analysis. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). The Pro-Gate loop faces toward the minor groove of RNA:DNA hybrid and is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. Taken together, this work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. This work also provides a framework for the development of new strategies for the prevention of mutagenesis and cancer. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease in humans. Virions require spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. We determined how sequential proteolysis contributes to MERS-CoV infection by introducing mutations that blocked the first cleavages. These mutations severely compromised MERS-CoV infection, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Consistent with these findings, uncleaved viruses trafficked past endosomal fusion-activating proteases into endosomes, whereas precleaved viruses used surface proteases to effect the second fusion-activating cleavages during cell entry. Uncleaved viruses were less infectious to human airway epithelial and Calu3 cell cultures because they lacked sufficient endosomal fusion-activating proteases. The food system is a major driver of environmental degradation and a leading cause of biodiversity loss. The food choices of the population have a major impact on the sustainability of the food system. This study shows that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a university cafeteria can have a significant impact on sales. This is a simple and low-cost intervention that could be implemented in other settings.

The cell surface proteome is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. It is a dynamic and complex system, and the surfaceome is a target for cancer therapy. Here we apply quantitative proteomics to the surfaceome of a breast epithelial cell line stably expressing a panel of six of the most prominent oncogenes, and find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. We complement the surfaceome data with whole cell glycoproteomics, and find massive oncogene-induced changes to the glycoproteome. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs, which allow voters to cast their ballots by mail. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We use a difference-in-differences design to estimate the effects of universal vote-by-mail on turnout and vote share. We find that universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our findings suggest that vote-by-mail programs are not likely to have a significant impact on the 2020 presidential election.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on the global community. The molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the disease is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is a rapidly evolving accessory protein that has been proposed to interfere with immune responses. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may be important for immune evasion. This work provides insight into the molecular basis of the COVID-19 pandemic and may lead to the development of new therapeutics. (Read less)

Hypoxia is a common condition in the human body, and it is also a major risk factor for cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms of cerebral edema induced by hypoxia are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and neuronal apoptosis in the cortex. We also show that the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus is increased, and that CRF acts on the CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1) in the cortex to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in cortical astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. These findings provide a molecular basis for the development of cerebral edema induced by hypobaric hypoxia. They also provide a molecular target for the prevention of cerebral edema in patients with severe hypoxia. (PsycINFO Database Record

The problem of selective inference is the challenge of assessing the strength of associations in a dataset that has been “cherry picked” for the strongest associations. This is a problem that is becoming more important in the era of big data and complex statistical modeling. We describe some recent new developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. The goal is to provide a framework for understanding the strengths of associations in a dataset, and to provide tools for making inferences about the strength of associations in a dataset.

The development of vascular ECs is a critical step in the formation of blood vessels. However, the development of ECs has been difficult to achieve in vitro and in vivo. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) can directly induce the development of vascular ECs from human fibroblasts. This study provides a new approach for the development of vascular ECs and may be useful for the treatment of vascular disorders. Furthermore, the development of ETVECs may be useful for the treatment of vascular disorders.

We report the discovery of a third class of RTKs, the augmentor receptors, and show that they are essential for the development of iridophores, the pigment cells of the zebrafish eye and skin. We also show that the augmentor ligands are essential for the development of iridophores in the skin and eye.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a major health problem worldwide. Although the molecular mechanisms of T2D are well established, the underlying molecular bases of insulin resistance and β-cell dysfunction remain to be further elucidated. Herein, we provide evidence that STING is required for normal β-cell function and plays an important role in the regulation of glucose homeostasis through peripheral tissues and β-cells. These findings establish pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. Furthermore, our study provides a potential target for the treatment of T2D. View Full-Text

Influenza A viruses are responsible for annual epidemics and occasional pandemics. Their genome is segmented into eight fragments, which offers evolutionary advantages but complicates genomic packaging. The existence of a selective packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is specifically packaged into each virion, is suspected, but its molecular details remain unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. Using this interaction, we showed that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. This study provides a molecular understanding of the packaging mechanism of influenza A virus and may help to develop new antiviral strategies. (PsycINFO Database Record

Atherosclerosis is the leading cause of death worldwide. The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a complex process that involves a series of events, including the activation of proatherosclerotic phenotypes of vascular endothelial cells. In this study, we demonstrate that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) is a critical event in the disturbed flow-induced activation of proatherosclerotic phenotypes of vascular endothelial cells. Our results provide a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atherosclerotic lesions and suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. This study also provides a rationale for the use of statin, an antiatherosclerotic drug, in the treatment of atherosclerosis. (PsycINFO Database Record

Wildfire is a natural process that has been an integral part of the natural landscape for millennia. However, in recent decades, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially. Climate change has likely contributed to the increase in wildfire activity, but the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Human-caused wildfires disproportionally occurred where fuel moisture was higher than lightning-started fires, thereby helping expand the geographic and seasonal niche of wildfire. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearance of five US cities with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our work also provides a proof of concept for a new approach to urban monitoring that can be applied to other cities and other types of data.

Natural repellents are a sustainable and ecofriendly alternative to synthetic pesticides. However, the molecular targets of natural repellents in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP) channel as a receptor of plant-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study provides a molecular insight into the arthropod–plant adaptation, and should help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. It should also help the understanding of the evolution of the plant–insect interaction. View Full-Text

The recent Zika virus (ZIKV) outbreak has been associated with severe fetal abnormalities and neurological complications. The mechanisms of ZIKV pathogenesis are not fully understood, but the dynamics of the virus within the host are likely to be important. Here we present a mathematical model of ZIKV dynamics in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We estimate that the eclipse phase for ZIKV, the time between cell infection and viral production, is most likely short (∼4 h), the median within-host basic reproductive number R0 is 10.7, the rate of viral production is rapid (>25,000 virions d−1), and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is ∼5 h. We also estimate that the minimum number of virions produced by an infected cell over its lifetime is ∼5,500. Finally, we assess the potential effect of an antiviral treatment that blocks viral replication, showing that the median time to undetectable plasma viral load can be reduced from ∼5 d to ∼3 d with a drug concentration ∼15 times the drug

Coral reefs are among the most biodiverse and valuable ecosystems on the planet. However, they are threatened by a variety of anthropogenic and natural stressors. In this study, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. This work is of particular relevance to the ongoing mass bleaching events, which are pushing coral reefs worldwide to the brink of ecological collapse.

The intestinal epithelium is the main barrier between the host and the environment. It is also the main site of nutrient absorption and immune surveillance. In this study, we show that the intestinal epithelium is also the main site of tumorigenesis in Drosophila. We identify a mechanism by which the tumorigenic state of the epithelium triggers a dysregulation of the microbiome, which in turn triggers a regenerative response that stimulates tumor growth. Our work identifies a mechanism by which the activity of the epithelium can be used to control the activity of the microbiome, and highlights the importance of controlling the activity of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer among women worldwide, and the leading cause of cancer death among women in the United States. Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but the response to chemotherapy is heterogeneous, and many patients do not respond to treatment. In this study, we show that the expression of the orphan receptor tyrosine kinase-like orphan receptor 1 (ROR1) is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy, and that ROR1 expression is associated with the capacity of breast cancer cells to metastasize and reengraft mice. Furthermore, we show that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab and chemotherapy was more effective than treatment with either alone in eradicating breast cancer PDXs. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Read more)

The timing of the start of accelerated deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere is a key piece of the climate puzzle, but the cause of this event is still debated. We show that the start of deglaciation is linked to a volcanic eruption series, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion and a change in climate.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food and livelihoods for hundreds of millions of people, but their importance is often overlooked. We present a global map of riverine fisheries, which we use to assess the role of inland fisheries in food security and biodiversity conservation. We find that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels, and that fish richness and catches are positively but not causally correlated. Merging our catch analysis with nutritional and socioeconomic data, we find that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people. This highlights the critical role of rivers and lakes in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein. At the same time, intensive fishing in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors may undermine efforts to conserve biodiversity. Our enhanced spatial data on estimated catches can facilitate the inclusion of inland fisheries in environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity. (Less)

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. Due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited. For achieving durable and high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries, the development of negative electrode materials exhibiting a large capacity and low potential without triggering decomposition of water is crucial. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2 delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅

The ability to regenerate after injury is a hallmark of the nervous system. However, in the adult mammalian CNS, neurons are unable to regenerate after injury, and the ability of the nervous system to regenerate is lost. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to be required for regeneration in the adult mammalian CNS. This discovery opens the door to a new platform for the discovery of genes that control regeneration in the adult nervous system.

The process of recombination is essential for the generation of genetic diversity in populations and species. However, the spatial and temporal patterns of recombination in the genome are not well understood. Here, we describe the spatial distribution of recombination in a wild population of the monkeyflower Mimulus guttatus. We find that recombination is highly variable across the genome, with some regions showing no evidence of recombination, and others showing intense activity. The distribution of recombination is similar to that observed in yeast and in mice, suggesting that the spatial pattern of recombination may be ancient and conserved.

The resting brain is a complex network of functionally connected regions, which can be identified by functional MRI. The present study provides a method to identify the resting state networks in healthy and disease populations, and to assess their functional relevance. The results show that the dominant resting state network in healthy subjects is topologically similar to the default mode network. In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease, this dominant network is subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern. Network deactivation was observed in early Parkinson’s disease, and was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. This study provides a method to assess the functional relevance of resting state networks, and to monitor their changes in health and disease.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA, and is essential for translation. We report the discovery of a second 5′ modification, the nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) RNA, which is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs in Saccharomyces cerevisiae. NAD-RNA appears to be produced cotranscriptionally, and only on subsets of pre-mRNAs that are not 5′ end processed. This discovery raises the possibility that the NAD-RNA cap could modulate RNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs. This could have important implications for the regulation of gene expression in eukaryotes.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in people with diabetes. We show that DNA methylation at specific loci in blood cells is associated with glycemia for several years during the follow-up of the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) and that this association is similar in both blood cells and in vitro in cultured blood monocytes. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory.
This study provides a mechanism for the role of FSIP1 in drug sensitivity of TNBC. Our findings may aid in the design of TNBC therapies.

Alcohol dependence is a chronic disease with a high social and economic impact. The present study shows that the gut barrier is altered in a significant proportion of alcohol-dependent subjects, and that this alteration is associated with the psychological symptoms of the disease. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in these subjects, suggesting that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of the gut barrier and in the behavioral symptoms of the disease. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals that contribute to the overall aroma. Among these volatiles are several that are nitrogenous, and their production is essential for fruit aroma. However, the biosynthetic pathways for these compounds are not known. Using an introgression population, we identified a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. Silencing of this gene in transgenic plants abolished production of the volatiles, and metabolomic analysis of the fruit revealed the accumulation of a known conjugate of cysteine and 3-methylbutanal. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato fruit flavor. (Read more)

We show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. This is important because temperature is one of the most profound threats to the functional integrity of the Earth’s ecosystems. We also show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key hub in the formation of spatial maps. It is thought to create a map of local space, based on the activity of grid, head-direction (HD), border, and object-vector (OV) cells. However, the anatomical and functional organization of these cell types is debated. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in freely behaving mice, and we found that grid cells are strongly coupled among themselves, but have weaker links to other cell types. These data suggest that grid cell networks might be largely distinct from those of border, HD, and OV cells. Our findings have implications for the development of neurotechnologies for studying the activity of neurons in the brain. (PsycINFO Database Record

Flowering is a complex process, which is controlled by a large number of genes. In this study, we show that the flowering signal FT is not required for the flowering of the host, but is required for the flowering of the parasite. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness.

The dopamine systems of the brain powerfully influence movement and motivation. We show that striatonigral fibers originating in striosomes form highly unusual bouquet-like arborizations that target clusters of dopamine-containing dendrites and their parent nigral cell bodies. These clustered cell bodies in turn project to the striatum as part of the classic nigrostriatal pathway. Thus, the striosome–dendron bouquets likely represent subsystems with the nigro–striato–nigral loop that are affected in human disorders including Parkinson’s disease. Given evidence that striosomes receive input from cortical regions related to the control of mood and motivation and that they link functionally to reinforcement and decision-making, the striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease.

We are social creatures, and we seek connection with others. We also seek to understand others, and we seek to be understood. In this study, we show that the speed at which people respond to each other is a robust signal of connection and understanding. This signal is used by others to gauge the quality of the connection between two people, and it is used by the people themselves to gauge their own connection with others.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the pacemaker of the heart and is responsible for the generation of the heartbeat. SAN cells are specialized cardiomyocytes that are responsible for the generation of the heartbeat. SAN cells are also known as sinus node cells. The SAN is a highly specialized cell type that is responsible for the generation of the heartbeat. This study reveals that the activity of the SAN is regulated by the activity of the sarcoplasmic reticulum, which is the storage system for calcium in the heart. This study also reveals that the activity of the sarcoplasmic reticulum is regulated by the activity of the plasma membrane. This study provides a mechanism by which the activity of the SAN is regulated, which may be important for the treatment of heart failure. (Read more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development, and its beneficial effects on plant resistance against abiotic and biotic stresses have been well documented. However, the role of Si in mediating insect herbivore defense responses has not been examined. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest, and that this effect is mediated by priming of jasmonate (JA)-mediated defense responses. Our results suggest that Si may be used as a biocontrol agent to protect rice from insect attack. This study also provides a framework for the development of Si-based biocontrol strategies for other crops. (Abridged)

This study provides a new perspective on the role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism. It also reveals that the cellular lipidome is a complex network of interactions and that the regulation of this network is not limited to the class of ether lipids.

Language is a complex system that requires the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in neuronal excitability that occur during learning. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Plants are the primary source of food for the human population, and the demand for food is increasing with the growing population. However, the supply of food is limited by the lack of efficient delivery of biomolecules to plants. Here, we report the delivery of biomolecules to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and location of the siRNA attachment locus on the DNA nanostructure are the key design parameters for the delivery of biomolecules to plants. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work will help in the development of DNA nanostructures as a tool for the delivery of biomolecules to plants.

Eutrophication is a major threat to the health of lakes and coastal ecosystems worldwide. In the United States, the majority of nutrient loading to lakes is from nonpoint sources, such as agricultural and urban runoff. However, the relative importance of small tributaries, which drain large watersheds, has been largely overlooked. We show that small tributaries can be a major source of nutrients to lakes, especially in the nearshore zone. Our findings suggest that nutrient management efforts should focus on small tributaries, which can be more effective at reducing coastal eutrophication than large tributaries. This approach could be applied to other large lakes and coastal areas worldwide.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in the presence of a strong thermodynamic forcing. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This finding is of interest in the context of the search for artificial life, as it suggests that the search for life in the universe may be biased toward systems that are already alive.

This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the mechanisms underlying the paroxysmal EEG abnormalities observed in patients with an autoimmune encephalitis caused by antibodies against the N-methyl-d-aspartate receptor. We show that the N-methyl-d-aspartate receptor is a critical target of the antibodies, and that the antibodies can change the dynamics of the cortical microcircuit, leading to changes in the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity. This work provides a framework for understanding the mechanisms of action of other autoimmune encephalitis therapies, and may also be relevant to other conditions in which changes in the dynamics of the cortical microcircuit can lead to clinical symptoms. This work also provides a framework for understanding the mechanisms of action of other autoimmune encephalitis therapies, and may also be relevant to other conditions in which changes in the dynamics of the cortical microcircuit can lead to clinical symptoms.

The history of Earth’s climate is recorded in the carbon cycle. This study provides a detailed reconstruction of a major climate perturbation that occurred during a glacial period. The study also provides insights into the role of the carbon cycle in the evolution of the Earth system.

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the leading certification scheme for palm oil, a major driver of tropical deforestation. We show that certification is associated with reduced deforestation, but that certification has no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results suggest that certification is not a silver bullet for tropical deforestation, but it is an important tool in the toolbox of policies and programs that are needed to achieve the goals of the Paris Climate Agreement.

The exocyst complex is a protein complex that is involved in the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. However, the study of the dynamic regulation of the exocyst-related processes using mutants in genetically tractable organisms such as Arabidopsis thaliana is limited by the lethality or the severity of phenotypes. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 (exocyst component of 70 kDa) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Less)

Sex determination is a key process in the evolution of vertebrates, and the number of sexes in a species is a key indicator of the evolutionary history of a species. In this study, we investigate the effects of multiple sex determination alleles on the evolution of secondary sexual characteristics in a fish species. We find that the number of sexes in a species is not fixed, but rather can be modular, allowing for the evolution of multiple sexes with different traits. This provides a framework for understanding the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations.

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by a variety of reactive oxygen species and reactive carbonyl species that can damage photoreceptor cells. We sought to understand how iron, which is essential for redox reactions, impacts the retina. We found that iron levels in retinal pigment epithelial cells, which are challenged by accumulation of vitamin A aldehyde adducts, promote the oxidation and degradation of a bisretinoid dye. These findings have implications for the retina and for other tissues challenged by reactive oxygen species and reactive carbonyl species. They also suggest that iron may be a target for the treatment of retinal diseases. This work provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of iron in the retina and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (PsycINFO Database Record

Predators are the main drivers of ecosystems, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is a key process in the development of biodiversity. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end, as it is often associated with the loss of morphological and functional adaptations. Here we show that siphonophores, a group of pelagic colonial cnidarians, can evolve into specialists on different prey types, and that these transitions are linked to the evolution of their tentacles and nematocysts. Our findings help to understand the evolution of specialization in predators, and the role of morphological innovation in the development of food webs.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolutionary biology. However, the origins of the derived features of the human hand are poorly understood because of the paucity of hand fossils in the hominin fossil record between 800,000 and 1.8 My old. Here we report the discovery of a hominin hand fossil from the Middle Pleistocene of Kenya that provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived feature of the human hand. This finding suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This study also highlights the potential of East African sites from the Middle Pleistocene to provide important insights into the evolution of the human hand. (Less)

Cancer is a disease of rapid cell growth, and thus requires a constant supply of one-carbon units. The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is a key regulator of this process, and is up-regulated in cancer. Here we report the discovery of a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT, and show that it blocks colon cancer tumor growth in mice. We also show that the one-carbon donor formate is a potent rescue of SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. This effect is rooted in defective glycine import, and thus defective glycine metabolism, in DLBCL. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of DLBCL. This work provides a metabolic target for the treatment of cancer. It also provides a framework for the design of small-molecule inhibitors of other enzymes that produce one-carbon units. This framework may be broadly applicable to the design of inhibitors of other metabolic pathways. (Read more)

This study shows that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets and dietary vitamin A adequacy. This is an important finding given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. The results have implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals.

Mechanization has been a key driver of the Green Revolution, the most successful agricultural revolution in history, with the expansion of food production and the reduction of hunger. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We hypothesize that the paradox of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction, including the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods, may be explained by the need to reduce subsoil compaction, including the use of fixed foraging trails, that guided these prehistoric giants. This may have been a key factor in the success of the Green Revolution. View Full-Text
